newsitem.title: JAPAN: Tokyo naphtha up slightly, physical buying emerges.
newsitem.headline: Tokyo naphtha up slightly, physical buying emerges.

text.p: Tokyo naphtha prices were slightly firmer on Wednesday, following overnight crude price gains in London, and also supported by physical buying, traders said.
"Offers are expected to edge up later today, supported by physical buying by a petrochemical product maker on Tuesday," a trader said.
Open-spec naphtha second-half March was assessed at about $231.00/232.50 and first-half April at $229.50/231.00, compared to $229.00/230.50 and $228.00/229.50 respectively on Tuesday.
The one-month spread from first-half April was barely changed at $2.50/4.00.
Traders said a Japanese petrochemical firm on Tuesday bought a first-March cargo at a high price of around $4.00 above the mean of Japanese quotes.

Other Japanese end-users are also probing the market for first-March cargoes, but are maintaining a cautious stance, traders said. This is because petrochemical firms are suffering profit declines as domestic product prices remain low, while naphtha prices are still at high levels.
In the jet kerosene market, a Japanese refiner bought a cargo on Monday, at about $2.20 above the mean of Singapore quotes, traders said.--Tokyo Energy Desk (81-3-5473-3708)
